title: Boston history quiz: How much do you remember from the past 30 years?
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Boston.com is celebrating its 30th anniversary with a quiz on major events since 1995.
The quiz challenges participants to order significant Boston events over the past three decades.
Kelly Chan, Boston.com content producer, invites users to share quiz results and provide feedback.

title: New on Netflix and more: Top streaming picks for November 2025
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: New movies on Netflix for November include 'Back to the Future,' 'Frances Ha,' and 'Game Night.'
Massachusetts-set movies like 'Hocus Pocus' and 'The Witch' recommended for Halloween streaming.
Highlights include HBO Max's 'Hereditary' and 'The Witch,' and Hulu's 'Thanksgiving.'

title: Rhamondre Stevenson misses multiple practices ahead of Falcons-Patriots
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Rhamondre Stevenson missed practices on Wednesday and Thursday due to a toe injury before the Falcons game.
Stevenson leads the Patriots with 279 rushing yards and three touchdowns despite three fumbles.
Rookie Treveyon Henderson and Terrell Jennings may lead the backfield if Stevenson is unavailable Sunday.

title: NFL execs believe Patriots are for real, but are a year away from Super Bowl contention
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Patriots hold a 6-2 record under coach Mike Vrabel and MVP candidate quarterback Drake Maye.
NFL executives view the Patriots as playoff contenders but not yet ready for Super Bowl contention.
Patriots have 6.8% odds of winning the AFC according to ESPN's FPI, with ESPN giving them 13th-best Super Bowl odds.

title: Before election day, meet Boston’s City Council candidates
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston's municipal election is on Nov. 4 with polls open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m.
Eight candidates are competing for four at-large City Council seats; several district seats are also contested.
Mayor Michelle Wu is running unopposed; major city issues include public drug use and autonomous vehicle policies.

title: Boston.com readers still pay for their adult children’s phone bills â€” and they’re not happy about it
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: One in five American adults remains on their parents' cellphone plan, down from 34% in 2022, per WhistleOut survey.
Boston.com readers express mixed feelings about supporting adult children's phone bills; 62% are GenX or baby boomer parents.
Some parents continue family phone plans to save money, despite considering it a financial and independence issue for their children.

title: Longtime political analyst Jon Keller among latest WBZ layoffs
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Jon Keller, longtime WBZ-TV political analyst, was laid off amid wider cuts at Paramount.
Paramount, newly acquired by Skydance Media, laid off around 2,000 employees nationwide.
Keller, known for political coverage, leaves WBZ after 20 years with recent columns in MASSter List.

title: Boston City Council District 7 race: Miniard Culpepper and Said Ahmed
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Miniard Culpepper and Said Ahmed are candidates for Boston City Council District 7 after Tania Fernandes Anderson's resignation.
Ahmed identifies housing crisis as District 7's main issue, proposing tenant protections and more affordable housing initiatives.
Ahmed emphasizes community engagement, proposing regular town halls and a local office to improve City Hall's public image.

title: Boston City Council District 6 race: Ben Weber and Steven Berry
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Incumbent Ben Weber faces Steven Berry in the Boston City Council District 6 race for the 2025 election.
Steven Berry emphasizes housing as the biggest issue, advocating for Accessory Dwelling Units and zoning changes.
Berry aims to represent underrepresented working-class individuals, promoting bold legislative actions to rebuild public trust.

title: Market Basket shopper says she found a widow spider in grapes
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Calista Plaisted found a widow spider in grapes bought from Market Basket in Lee, New Hampshire.
Plaisted identified the spider with help from a University of New Hampshire expert.
Market Basket was informed and stated the grapes were sold out, planning to notify the supplier.
